# Introduction

To use Quarto/Markdown you should install the [`quarto`](https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/) program. And to use it in VS Code you need to have the `Quarto VS Code Extension`. 

In python it would also require installing the following libraries most commonly required by quarto: `jupyter`, `ipykernel`, `nbformat`, `nbclient`, `pyyaml`.

Once the document is ready to generate a result just click `Preview` button on right hand side of the top bar of VS Code.

The text inside Quarto documents is written in Markdown. Markdown is a simple set of conventions for adding formatting to plain text.

## This starts a new subchapter

Your document can be organized in (sub)capters.
One can also use itemization:

* this is item 1,
* there might be a second one,
    + subitems are possible as well
    + there might be more of them,
* in fact as many as you wish.

Numbered lists are also possible:

1. this is item number 1 again,
2. there might be a second one,
    + subitems are possible as well
    + there might be more of them,
        + subsubitems are also allowed
3. in fact as many as you wish.
 

## Second subchapter

If you want to emphasize text -- use a star \* for *italics* or double star \*\* for **bolded text** (slash \\ turns off a special meaning of characters). 

For more details please check the [Markdown basics](https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/markdown-basics.html), [Quarto guide](https://quarto.org/docs/guide/) or [Tutorials](https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/hello/vscode.html).


## Subchapter no 3 -- code chunks

But the most interesting feature is the possibility of creating a `dynamic document` -- mix text with python code and python results -- this is done in so called `code chunks` -- see below for examples.

### Example 1

This chunk prints the code, evaluates it and prints the results 

```{python}
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

# Generate 1000 random values from a standard normal distribution
a = np.random.normal(size=1000)

# Use pandas to get a summary
summary = pd.Series(a).describe()
print(summary)
```

### Example 2

By using an additional chunk option `#|eval: false` you can for example see just the code and not the results (the code is printed, but not executed/evaluated):

```{python}
#|eval: false
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

# Generate 1000 random values from a standard normal distribution
a = np.random.normal(size=1000)

# Use pandas to get a summary
summary = pd.Series(a).describe()
print(summary)
```

### Example 3

or the opposite -- by using the option `#|echo: false` you can see just the results and not the code

```{python}
#|echo: false
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

# Generate 1000 random values from a standard normal distribution
a = np.random.normal(size=1000)

# Use pandas to get a summary
summary = pd.Series(a).describe()
print(summary)
```

### Example 4

you can load additional packages without showing that in the output file (CAUTION! packages should be installed BEFORE, e.g. in a console window):

```{python}
#|echo: false
import yfinance as yf
```

### Example 5

If you want to avoid warnings, you can use another chunk options `#/warning: false`. More options can be found here: [Quarto chunk execution options](https://quarto.org/docs/computations/execution-options.html)

```{python}
#|echo: false
#|warning: false

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
```

### Example 6

Then you can use functions from the loaded package in the following chunks, e.g.

```{python}
AAPL = yf.download("AAPL", # symbol/ticker
                    start = "2005-01-01",
                    end = "2025-09-30")
AAPL.tail()
```

### Example 7

One can also generate plots in the output document.

```{python}
# lets change column names so that they are more readible
AAPL.columns = [f"{price.lower()}_{ticker}" for price, ticker in AAPL.columns]

# and make a plot
AAPL['close_AAPL'].plot(title = "Quotations of Apple (2005-2025)")
```


### Example 8

When generating plots, one can use additional plotting options

```{python}
#| echo: false
#| label: fig-AAPL
#| fig-cap: "Adjusted close of AAPL"
#| fig-align: "right"
#| fig-height: 4
#| fig-width: 6

plt.plot(AAPL['close_AAPL'], color='darkblue')
plt.title("Adjusted close price of Apple")
plt.grid(True, linestyle='--', linewidth=0.5)
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```


### Example 9

One can also refer to results of Python objects inline in the text.

Inline expressions should be confined to simple values that you have pre-computed within normal code cells (rather than function calls that do non-trivial work). This is because the protocol used for inline expressions is not compatible with some Python libraries (especially those that use multi-threading or multi-processing).

```{python}
#| echo: false

date1 = AAPL.index[-1].date()
```

For example: on `{python} date1.strftime('%Y-%m-%d')` Apple quotations started with the price of `{python} round(AAPL['open_AAPL'][-1].item(), 2)`\$ to finish a day on a level of `{python} round(AAPL['close_AAPL'][-1].item(), 2)`\$ with the volume of trading equal to `{python} int(AAPL['volume_AAPL'][-1])` units.

## Dollars in Quarto/Markdown

We had to mask a dollar (\$) sign in the above examples as it has a special meaning in Markdown -- very similar to LaTeX -- it can be used to indicate a mathematical formulea, for example: $x_{1+s}^{2*d}$, $\frac{y^2}{x_{1t}}$, $y_t = \alpha_0 + \phi_1 x_{1,t} + \epsilon_t$.

For more examples see: [here](https://qmd4sci.njtierney.com/math.html) or anything else.
